text: tension on the edge of India's capital
city protesters demanding that they be
given affirmative action job quotas
they've taken a position on the highway
using whatever they can get their hands
on to block the way this is one of the
main highways leading into Delhi and
this is the only way these people who
are trying to get to work and come in on
foot because this highway has been
blocked for a couple of days now there
are young men here who are preventing
people from coming through no supplies
are coming into the city because they've
set up these temporary barricades so
trucks buses or any cars are blocked
Delhi effectively has been encircled
there is no way of coming in and there's
no way of going out we are prevented
from filming further by the protesters
we have been sitting here at this border
for the past seven to eight days no one
has come here to meet us we have been
provoked unnecessarily we want peace but
instead we have been beaten up over the
weekend the police use force to break up
some of the demonstrations
the protesters responded with violence
government property buses and trains
were set on fire all attempts to call
for peace have so far failed sanjay
Majumdar BBC news Delhi Haryana border
